title-group.article-title: Supramolecular Self-assembly of Monoend-functionalized Methoxy Poly(ethylene glycol) and α-Cyclodextrin: From Micelles to Hydrogel

article-meta.aff: National Engineering Research Center for Biomaterials, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064 China

author-notes.corresp: Bin He, National Engineering Research Center for Biomaterials, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064 China. Email: bhe@scu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An effective strategy was developed to fabricate a supramolecular hydrogel with the complexation of α-cyclodextrins (α-CDs) and monoend-functionalized low molecular weight methoxy poly(ethylene glycol) (mPEG, Mn=2000) micelles. Hydrophobic cinnamic acid was immobilized on methoxy poly(ethylene glycol) via L-lysine as linker to prepare amphiphilic mPEG. The monoend-functionalized mPEG self-assembled micelles in aqueous solution. The size and size distribution of the micelles were tested by dynamic laser scattering (DLS). The morphology of the micelles was observed by SEM, TEM and AFM. The critical micelle concentration (CMC) was tested and it was 42.5 mg/L. The monodisperse micelles had core-shell structure and the mean diameter was around 40 nanometers. α-cyclodextrins were added in the suspension of micelles to form supramolecular hydrogel with the polypseudorotaxanes complexation. Hydrophilic drug doxorubicin hydrochloride was used as model drug to study the release profile. The results showed that the hydrogel was a promising carrier for drug delivery.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, supramolecular hydrogels have attracted considerable attention because of their potential applications in drug delivery and tissue engineering [1–7]. Design and construction of supramolecular hydrogels systems through host–guest interaction have been extensively studied [8–12]. Cyclodextrins (CDs) are widely-recognized as hosts to form inclusion complex with guest molecules via non-covalent interactions [13–18]. The driven forces for the complexation were considered as intermolecular hydrogen bonding between neighboring CDs as well as steric compatibility and hydrophobic interactions between host and guest molecules [19–22]. The inclusion complexes composed of CDs and polymers were called polypseudorotaxanes or polyrotaxanes [14, 23–27]. The complexation could be used to fabricate supramolecular hydrogels for medical applications. Yui et al. synthesized PEG/α-CD polyrotaxanes capped with amino acids, polypeptides and oligopeptides, which were used as biodegradable drug carriers or stimuli responsive hydrogels [28–29]. Huh et al. prepared the graft copolymers containing dextran as backbones and PEG or PPG as side chains, while the CDs were threaded into PEG or PPG chains to form hydrogel [30–31]. PEG with high molecular weight was considered as a necessity for the formation of stable hydrogels. Li and coworkers firstly reported the sol-gel transition during complex formation between α-CD and high molecular weight PEG in aqueous solution in 1994 [32]. A thermo-reversible polyrotaxane hydrogel containing high molecular weight PEG and methylated α-CD was studied by Kataoka et al. [33]. It was known that PEG with high molecular weight (normally Mn>10K) was unfavorable for ﬁltration through the human kidney membrane due to their large hydrodynamic radius and easiness of forming crystals of stoichiometric complexes [34]. Therefore, low molecular weight PEG based supramolecular hydrogels were desirable for pharmaceutical or medicinal applications. Jiang and coworkers utilized micelle-hydrogel transition approach to fabricate supramolecular hydrogel. The micelles of inclusion complex of adamantane and monoend-functionalized PEG were transited to hydrogel with the addition of α-cyclodextrins. Low molecular weight PEG of Mn=2000 was used in the transition [35].

In our previous work, polypseudorotaxane based supramolecular hydrogel containing mPEG grafted (Mn=750 and 2000) poly(L-malic acid) with comb-like architecture and α-cyclodextrins were prepared and used for anti-tumor drug delivery [36]. In the present work, a new supramolecular hydrogel was reported using micelle-hydrogel transition approach. Hydrophobic moiety cinnamic acid was connected to mPEG2000 using L-lysine as linkers. The amphiphilic mPEG spontaneously self-assembled into micelles in phosphate buffer saline (PBS) solution. With the addition of α-cyclodextrins, the micelles were transited to hydrogel. The structures and properties of micelles and the hydrogel were characterized. Preliminary investigations of cytotoxicity and release profile of the hydrogel for drug delivery were also reported.

sec.title: Experimental Section
sec.p: Materials. Cinnamic acid and thionyl chloride were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). 1-Hydroxy-Benzotriazole monohydrate (HOBT), 2-(1H-Benzotriazole -1-yl)-1, 1, 3, 3-tetramethyluroniumhexafluorophosphate (HBTU), L-Lysine dihydrochloride, N, N-Diisopropylethylamine (DIEA) were purchased from GL Biochem. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). N, N-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC), alpha-methoxy-ω- amino-poly (ethylene glycol) (mPEGNH2, Mw: 2000g/mol), α-Cyclodextrin (α-CD), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. and used as received. Acetic ester, dimethylformamide (DMF), diethyl ether, petroleum ether, dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), chloroform (CHCl3), ethanol, methanol, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), sodium Bicarbonate (NaHCO3)sodium bisulfate (NaHSO4), sodium chloride (NaCl), anhydrous magnesium sulfate, and hydrogen chloride (HCl) were purchased from Kelong Chemical Co. (Chengdu, China). All the solvents were used without further purification except DMF and CH2Cl2.

Characterizations. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II NMR spectrometer at 400 MHz using CDCl3 and DMSO as solvents with 0.5% tetramethylsilane as the internal standard. The CMC of the amphiphilic mPEG was determined with fluorescence spectroscopy (F-7000, Hitachi). The dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements were performed at 25 °C on a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS at the scattering angle θ=90°. The morphology observation of the micelles was performed by Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) (MFP-3D-BIO, Asylum Research), Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) (S-4800, HITACHI), and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) (H-600 Electron Microscope). A drop of micelle solution (0.1 mg/mL) was deposited onto mica and copper grids to prepare the specimens for AFM, SEM and TEM. The specimens were air-dried. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in dynamic nitrogen atmosphere using the Netzsch STA499C system. The heating temperature was programmed from 35 to 600°C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed on TA DSC Q2000 Differential Scanning Calorimeter. The measurement procedure was as follows: the samples were heated from room temperature to 150°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min and kept at 150°C for 2 min (to eliminate the thermal history). The samples were then cooled to −90°C with a cooling rate of 10°C/min. After remaining for 2 min, the samples were heated to 150°C again at a heating rate of 10°C/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on Philips X’ Pert pro MPD with Cu Kα (ν=0.154nm) radiation source, the supplied voltage and current were set to 40 KV and 25 mA, respectively. The samples were mounted on a sample holder and scanned from 2° to 50° at a step size of 0.02°. Turbidity measurements were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 650S UV-vis spectrophotometer at a ﬁxed wavelength of 550 nm at room temperature. For the SEM observations, the specimens were freeze dried under vacuum. The dried specimens were coated with gold vapor and analyzed on a Hitachi S-4800 electron microscope.

Synthesis of Methyl L-lysinate dihydrochloride (Lys-OMe·2HCl)·L-Lysine dihydrochloride (5 g, 27 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (50 mL) and the solution was cooled in an ice bath. Subsequently, thionyl chloride (2.35 mL, 32.4 mmol) was added dropwise into the solution under stirring. The mixture was then warmed to room temperature. After 12 hours’ stirring, the mixture was concentrated in vacuum system, and precipitated in excess cold diethyl ether. The product was separated by filtration and dried at room temperature in vacuum overnight.

Synthesis of Double-Cinnamic Methyl L-lysine Lys-OMe·2HCl (10 mmol), Cinnamic acid (40 mmol), HOBT (20 mmol) and HBTU (20 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL DMF and the solution was cooled in an ice bath. Subsequently, DIEA (0.1 mol) was added dropwise into the solution under stirring. After stirred at room temperature for 24 hours, the solvent was removed by rotatory evaporator. The crude product was dissolved in 50 mL CHCl3 and then washed with saturated NaHCO3, NaHSO4, brine solutions, respectively. After being dried with anhydrous magnesium sulfate, the product was evaporated to pale yellow oil. The crude product was purified by column chromatography. The product was then precipitated in excess cold diethyl ether, collected by filtration and vacuum-dried. 1H NMR (DMSO, δ): 8.49 (d, 1H, 8’), 8.14 (t, 1H, 8), 6.73 (d, 1H, 7’), 6.60 (d, 1H, 7), 4.36 (q, 1H, 5), 3.65 (s, 3H, -COOCH3). The number like 8’ was on behalf of the protons as illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
The 1H NMR spectra of DCIN-Lys-OMe, DCIN-Lys and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000.

Deprotection of the Methyl groups on was dissolved in methanol (2 mL) and the solution was cooled in an ice bath. Subsequently, 1M NaOH aqueous solution (2 mL) was added dropwise into the mixture and stirred at room temperature for 12 hours. Methanol in the mixture was removed using rotatory evaporator. 1M HCl was then added into the aqueous solution under stirring to maintain the pH at 2. White powder was separated by filtration and washed with deionized water. Finally, the powder was dried at room temperature in vacuum overnight. 1H NMR (DMSO, δ): 12.61 (brs, 1H, -COOH), 8.36 (d, 1H, 8’), 8.12 (t, 1H, 8), 6.75 (d, 1H, 7’), 6.61 (d, 1H, 7), 4.32 (q, 1H, 5). The number like 8’ was on behalf of the protons as illustrated in Figure 1.

Synthesis of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000. DCC (0.111 g, 0.54 mmol) was added in the dichloromethane (CH2Cl2, 10 mL) solution containing alpha-methoxy-ω-amino-poly(ethylene glycol) (mPEGNH2, Mw: 2000 g/mol) (0.6g, 0.3mmol), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) (0.02 g, 0.18 mmol) and DCIN-Lys (0.18 g, 0.36 mmol). The mixture was stirred under nitrogen at room temperature for 24 h. The reaction was stopped by addition of deionized water (0.5 mL). After the removal of solvent, the residual oil was poured into anhydrous diethyl ether. The white precipitate was filtered and washed with diethyl ether. The product was recrystallized in ethanol and vacuum-dried. The product was dissolved in deionized water and dialyzed against deionized water using a dialysis membrane (MWCO 2000). After three days’ dialysis, the solution inside the membrane was freeze-dried (yield=90%). 1H NMR (CDCl3, δ): 7.64 (d, 1H, 8’), 7.61 (t, 1H, 8), 6.60 (d, 1H, 7’), 6.52 (d, 1H, 7), 4.54 (q, 1H, 5), 3.38 (s, 3H, -OCH3). The number like 8’ was on behalf of the protons as illustrated in Figure 1.

Formation of Hydrogels. General process for the hydrogel formation is as follows: 1 mL aqueous solution of α-CD (200 mg/mL) was added in 1 mL 50 mg/mL aqueous solution of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000. The gelation was accelerated by sonication.

Cytotoxicity Tests. Mouse embryonic ﬁbroblasts NIH/3T3 were cultured in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM; Gibco) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS; Hyclone) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin (Gibco). The cells were grown in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 and 95% air at 37°C. Extracts for indirect tests were prepared in accordance with International Organization for Standardization (ISO) tests (ISO 10993-5). The hydrogels were extracted using complete culture medium at 37°C for 24 h. The complete culture medium was used as control. The extracts from 0.15, 0.10, and 0.05 g/mL dilutions were added to NIH/3T3 cells that seeded in 96-multiwell plates. After incubated for 24 h, the cultures were evaluated for cell viability by MTT assay. The culture medium was replaced with 0.1 mL/well of MTT solution (1 mg/mL). After 3 h of incubation at 37°C, the solution was removed and 0.1 mL/well of DMSO was added. The absorbance of the formazan product was then measured at a wavelength of 492 nm.

In vitro drug release. The In vitro release profile was performed in a similar manner as reported by Jeong et al [37]. Briefly, 12.5 mg DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 was dissolved in 0.25 mL 0.2 mg/mL DOX·HCl PBS solution (pH=7.4), 50 mg α-CD was dissolved in 0.25 mL PBS solution (pH=7.4). The gelation was occurred within several minutes after mixing in screw-capped test tubes. The hydrogel was stood in refrigerator overnight, and then 5 mL PBS was introduced and the tubes were incubated at 37°C. At regular intervals, 1 mL supernatant liquid was withdrawn and replenished with 1 mL fresh PBS. Absorbance of the released DOX·HCl was read at 480 nm in fluorescence spectroscopy (F-7000, Hitachi). All experiments were done in triplicate.

Statistical Analysis. All experiments were conducted in triplicate. Single factor analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Tukey’s HSD (honestly significantly different) multiple comparison tests were used to determine statistical significance of results with a 95% confidence interval (α=0.05). The results are reported as means±standard deviation.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p:
Amphiphilic block copolymers were intensively studied to fabricate micelles [38–40], the balance between hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity was important to the formation of micelles. Unlike traditional polymeric micelles, a new micelles containing amphiphilic PEG with mono-end hydrophobic moiety was synthesized (scheme 1). L-lysine was used as linker to connect methoxy poly(ethylene glycol) (mPEG) and hydrophobic cinnamic acid. Two cinnamic acid molecules were immobilized on the amino groups of L-lysine. The amphiphilic mPEG self-assembled into micelles with cinnamate as hydrophobic core and mPEG as hydrophilic shell. Scheme 1.
The synthesis and self-assembly of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000.

The 1H NMR spectra of the amphiphilic PEG were presented in Figure 1. In the spectra of DCIN-Lys-OMe, it was noteworthy that the chemical shift of the protons in methyl ester (6, COOCH3) appeared at δ=3.65 ppm. The chemical shifts of protons in L-lysine were around δ=4.36 ppm (5, CHCOOCH3), 3.17 ppm (1, CONHCH2) and 1.35-1.72 ppm (2, 3, 4, CH2CH2CH2). The protons in cinnamate were localized from δ=6 to 9 ppm. The signals of protons in CH=CH split four peaks. The signals of the protons connected to benzenewere were around δ=8.49 ppm (8’) and 8.14 ppm (8) and the others were around δ=6.73 ppm (7’) and 6.60 ppm (7). The chemical shift of protons in the benzene ring appeared in two sites. The peak at δ=7.55 ppm was attributed to the protons in the ortho position, while the protons in the meta and para position were at δ=7.38 ppm. According to the integrities of the L-lysine units and cinnamate groups, the ratio of lysine/cinnamic was 1/2, which indicated that two cinnamic acid molecules were immobilized on L-lysine.

In the spectra of DCIN-Lys, it was noteworthy that the broad single peak at δ=12.61 ppm was corresponded to the proton in carboxyl group (COOH). The protons in methyl ester (6, COOCH3) at δ=3.65 ppm disappeared. It implied that the deprotection was successful. The signal at δ=8.36 ppm was the protons of 8’ which shifted from 8.49 ppm (in the spectrum of DCIN-Lys-OMe) to 8.36 ppm. The proton 5 was shifted from δ=4.36 ppm to 4.32 ppm. The other peaks were not obviously changed.

In the spectra of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, the protons of 14 and 15 (CH2CH2O) in the PEG chain appeared at δ=3.68 ppm. The chemical shift of the protons in the terminal CH3 (16) groups was at δ=3.38 ppm. Because of the solvent change, the chemical shift the protons in CH=CH was changed dramatically, for example, the shift of the proton 8’ was shifted from δ=8.36 ppm to 7.64 ppm, and that of proton 8 was changed from δ=8.12 ppm to 7.61 ppm. The chemical shift of the proton 7’ and 7 appeared at δ=6.60 ppm and 6.52 ppm, respectively. Protons 5 located at δ=4.54 ppm. The chemical shift of protons in the benzene ring still appeared in two peaks, which appeared at δ=7.46 ppm for ortho position and δ=7.32 ppm for meta and para positions.

The CMC of the micelles were measured by a steady state pyrene fluorescence method as previously reported [41], the calculation of the CMC of amphiphilic mPEG was shown in Figure 2. The calculated CMC of the micelles was 42.5mg/L. Figure 2.
The CMC of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles.

The size and size distribution of the micelles were tested by DLS and Figure 3 showed the results. The micelles were monodisperse in water. The average diameter of the micelles was around 40 nanometers and the size distribution was unimodal (PDI = 0.386, Width = 40 ± 10.36 nm). Figure 3.
Dynamic light scattering analysis of the average diameter of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles (concentration: 50 ug/mL).

The morphology of the DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles was observed by SEM, TEM and AFM (Figure 4). The micelles in the photographs were spherical nanoparticles, the sizes of the micelles were different. In the SEM, TEM, AFM photographs, micelles with different diameters were observed, the diameter of the big micelles was about 100 nanometers and that of the small ones was about 40 nanometers. It was a normal phenomena in micrographs in the morphology study of micelles because the sizes of the micelles were distributed in a certain range, the micelles with different diameters existed at the same time [38–40]. Figure 4.
The morphology of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles, (a), SEM photograph; (b), TEM photograph; (c), AFM photograph.

As we known, α-CD and low molecular weight PEG could not form homogeneous hydrogel but precipitate which actually comprised crystalline complexes of the PEG/α-CD polypseudorotaxanes [34, 35]. Two strategies were carried out to prepare a homogeneous hydrogel of α-CD and low molecular weight PEG. One was to reduce the amount of the threaded CDs to avoid the formation of inclusion complex precipitate, and the other was to end-functionalize mPEG to form micelles as the guests [35].

The supramolecular hydrogel was obtained after the aqueous solutions of α-cyclodextrins and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles were mixed together. The hydrogel was illustrated in Figure 5. Sonication could accelerate the gelation process during the hydrogel formation. It was reported that the driving forces for this type hydrogel were the combination of the inclusion complexation between α-CD and PEG chains as well as the aggregation of the hydrophobic moieties in the amphiphilic polymers [16, 17, 34, 42]. Therefore, the gelation of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles and α-CDs was induced by both the microcrystalline domains of the α-CD/PEG inclusion complex and the hydrophobic aggregation domains of cinnamate groups (as shown in Scheme 2). Jiang and coworkers reported the similar approach to prepare supramolecular hydrogel, which was called supra-crosslink [35]. With the comparison of Jiang’s approach of adamantane monoend-functionalized low-molecular-weight PEG, DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles had lower CMC and they were more convenient to form supramolecular hydrogel. Scheme 2.
Schematic representation of the supramolecular hydrogels of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 and α-CDs. Figure 5.
Photographs in the process of hydrogel formation: (a) aqueous solutions of α-CDs and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles, (b) invertible supermolecular hydrogels formed 10 min after mixed. The concentrations of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 and α-CD were 15 mg/mL and 100 mg/mL, respectively.

The turbidity of the solution of α-CDs and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles was measured. It increased rapidly with time increasing (Figure 6). The turbidity was stable after mixed for 50 seconds, the transmission efficiency was from about 70% to below 5%. It indicated that the gelation occurred rapidly and the α-cyclodextrins threaded in the PEG chains spontaneously. Figure 6.
Evolution curves of optical transparency versus time after the addition of α-CD solution to DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, without stirring at room temperature. The concentrations of α-CD and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 were 25 mg/mL and 100 mg/mL, respectively.

The wide-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of α-CD, DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, and the complexes were presented in Figure 7. Strong peaks at 2θ=12.48°, 13.41° and 22.15° were observed in the spectrum of pure α-CDs. Meanwhile, the polymer DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 exhibited two strong peaks at 2θ=19.15° and 23.35°, respectively. After the gelation, a strong peak at 2θ=20.05° and a weak peak at 2θ=22.76° were observed, which were characteristic of peaks of α-CD /PEG based IC crystals adopting a channel structure [20–21, 23, 43–46]. Two peaks (about 12.08° and 16.15°) associated with the random structure of α-CD also existed in Figure 7C (freeze-dried hydrogel). This indicated that there were both complex and un-complex α-CDs in the hydrogel [16–17, 32, 47–49]. Figure 7.
X-ray diffraction power patterns for (A) α-CDs, (B) DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, (C) freeze-dried hydrogel. For the hydrogel sample, the concentrations of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 and α-CD were 25 and 100 mg/mL, respectively.

TGA thermal analysis is a forceful technique to prove the supramolecular interaction between guest and host molecules in inclusion complexs [16–17, 47–49]. TGA measurements for α-CDs (A), DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 (B), and freeze-dried hydrogel (C) were illustrated in Figure 8. Here, the decomposition temperature (Td) to evaluate the thermal stability of the supramolecular structured hydrogel was set when 10% of mass loss had occurred. All the decomposition temperatures, end temperatures, and residual mass of the three chemicals were summarized in Table 1. The Td value for α-CDs was 316 °C, while it was 389 °C for DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000. Moreover, the end temperatures of the decomposition were 332 °C and 425 °C. The residual mass of the α-CD and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 at 600 °C were 10.83% and 5.71%. However, as shown in Figure 8, two apparent weight loss transitions were observed in the TGA curves of the freeze-dried hydrogel. The thermal degradation process was composed of two steps, one could be attributed to the decomposition of α-CD, while the other was attributed to the DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000. The Td value for freeze-dried hydrogel was between those of α-CDs and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000. The first decomposition temperature was 324 °C, and the first end temperature of the decomposition was 339 °C. The second decomposition temperature was 389 °C and the second end temperature was 412 °C. The residual mass of the freeze-dried hydrogel at 600 °C was 14.41%. These results suggested that the inclusion complexation between α-CD and the amphiphilic mPEG micelles occurred during the gelation and the polypseudorotaxane formed as physical crosslink [16, 17, 47–49]. Figure 8.
TGA curves of (A) α-CDs, (B) DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, (C) freeze-dried hydrogel. Table 1.
The TGA results of α-CD, DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 and hydrogel
α-CD DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 Freeze-dried hydrogel
Threshold(°C) 316.6 389.2 323.7 388.8
End(°C) 331.7 425.1 338.6 418.3
Residual Mass(%) 10.83 5.71 14.41

DSC measurement was used to investigate the thermal property of the freeze-dried hydrogel. The second heating scan DSC curves were illustrated in Figure 9. As shown in Figure 9, no endothermal peak was observed in the heating scan of α-CDs (A) and the endothermal peak for the DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 (B) was observed at 52.62 °C. However, no endothermal peak for DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 was observed in the heating scan of freeze-dried hydrogel (C), it suggested that the crystallization of PEG was severely limited in the α-CD cavity. In the second heating scan DSC curves, no obvious glass transition was founded, and the glass transitions of PEG became indistinct after the IC formation with α-CD. It could be deduced that the segmental mobility of the guest molecular chain was completely suppressed in the α-CD cavity [14, 16, 17, 47–50]. Figure 9.
The second heating DSC curves of (A) α-CD, (B) DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, (C) Freeze-dried hydrogel.

The cooling scan DSC curves were used to study the crystallization behavior as shown in Figure 10. No distinct crystallization peak was detected in the cooling scan of α-CD and the obvious crystallization peak of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 was observed at 19.48 °C. The crystallization peak of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 became unclear after the IC formation. It indicated that the crystallization of the guest DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 was fully restricted in the α-CD cavity. Figure 10.
The cooling DSC curves of (A) α-CD, (B) DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000, (C) freeze-dried hydrogel.

The morphology of the freeze-dried hydrogel was revealed by SEM. This hydrogel displayed a relatively homogeneous three-dimensional porous gel structure. The diameters of pores were from several micrometers to tens of micrometers (Figure 11). Figure 11.
SEM images of the freeze-dried hydrogel in different amplifications.

The in vitro cytotoxicity tests (MTT assay) were performed using the mouse NIH/3T3 cell line and the results were shown in Figure 12. The absorbance values observed with the hydrogel extracts, even at the higher concentrations, were comparable to that of the control (medium without material extracts). The extracts induced non-toxic in either cell viability reduction or inhibition of cell growth. Figure 12.
Cytotoxicity evaluation of hydrogels using mouse NIH/ 3T3 cell line at different extract dilutions by MTT assay, the absorbance values were proportional to the number of viable cells and were expressed as percentage of the control values that were given as 100%. The control was represented by the extraction vehicle without material. The data were expressed as mean ± standard deviation.

The anti-tumor drug doxorubicin hydrochloride was used as model drug to study the release profile of the hydrogel. Aqueous solutions of α-CDs and DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 micelles were mixed together, the solution formed pink opaque hydrogel within several minutes, sonication and lower temperature could accelerate the gelation process.

The release profile of α-CD /DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 supramolecular hydrogel was evaluated in vitro. The cumulative release of DOX·HCl from α-CD /DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 hydrogel was shown in Figure 13. It was presumed that the diffusion of DOX·HCl and the erosion of hydrogel through de-threading of PEG chains from CD cavities contributed to the release. The accumulated release rate was about 49% in the first 10 hours. The release rate was slow down after that and it was nearly a linear release till 20 hours. The total release rate was more than 75% and the sustaining release time was 120 hours. Figure 13.
In vitro release proﬁle of DOX.HCl from the hydrogel, the concentration of DCIN-Lys-mPEG2000 and α-CD were 25 mg/mL and 100 mg/mL, respectively.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This work presented a simple and effective approach to prepare supramolecular hydrogel with cinnamate monoend-functionalized low molecular weight mPEG micelles and α-CDs. The critical micelle concentration of amphiphilic mPEG micelles was 42.5 mg/mL. The micelles had core-shell structure and were monodispersed in water. The hydrogel was formed with the addition of α-cyclodextrins. The driving forces for the gelation were both the microcrystalline domains inclusion complexes and the hydrophobic aggregation of cinnamate moieties. The hydrogel was non-toxic and doxorubicin hydrochloride could persistently release from the hydrogel. Thus, the hydrogel is a promising injectable hydrogel used for in-situ therapeutics.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: This research work was supported by the National Basic Research Program of China (National 973 program, No. 2011CB606206), National Science Foundation of China (NSFC, No. 20604016, 50830105), Sichuan Youth Science & Technology Foundation (No. 07ZQ026-013) and Open Fund of Engineering Research Center of Biomass Materials, Ministry of Education (No. 2010LF4002).
